item.title: Electronic Frontier Foundation
item.description: The Patent Trial and Appeal Board should hear cases on the merits, not just throw out patent challengers they don’t like. https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/06/our-right-challenge-junk-patents-under-threat

item.description:

So.
No?
https://twitter.com/BFriedmanDC/status/1665467512891252738

item.title: MAHanson
item.description: Maybe the most impactful talk I've seen in the last few years was a simple weekly talk by a dept post-doc.The article I just shared (https://fediscience.org/@MarkHanson/110489681649296930) reminded me of this talk... thinking about science exploration...What was special? I asked a question that got laughed at by the speaker and room. I've wondered ever since whether that was because I was just ignorant? Or was everyone else just creatively restrained? I still don't know the answer... 1/n#AcademicChatter

item.title: Giorgio Gilestro
item.description:
This is a cute elephant. Elephants spend up to 18 hours a day eating grass, bushes, roots, shrubs to maintain their appropriate calorie intake. They sleep only for 1 or 2 hours a day.
1/17

item.title: Giorgio Gilestro
item.description: What is the take-home message? Well, we try to figure out what all this means in evolutionary terms. We think sleep has different functions in different species (doh!) and some functions therefore evolved for some species but not others.

item.title: Giorgio Gilestro
item.description: Evolution is one of the great mysteries of sleep. Why do some animals require 20 h, while others can cope with 1? Whatever sleep function is, how can it be accomplished in 10 hours in one season and 40 minutes in another, as it happens in migratory birds? We won't really understand what sleep is and what it does if we keep thinking about it in an anthropocentric way. We need to look at it from the evolutionary standpoint and only then we will be able to grasp what its role in nature is. 5/24

item.title: Tim Bray
item.description: 1/2 Open Letter from Stack Exchange moderators: They’re going on moderation strike due to being forbidden from stemming the flow of LLM spam: https://openletter.mousetail.nl

item.title: Megan Lynch (she/her)
item.description: The White House Office of Science & Technology Policy is having a number of listening sessions on Open Science June 5, 6, and 12. Good opportunity for marginalized scientists to weigh in.https://www.whitehouse.gov/ostp/events-webinars/#OpenScience #DisabledInSTEM #MarginSci

item.title: Richard Sever
item.description: An interview with Elaine Fuchs.https://youtu.be/EWaMXZFQyn0We talk about stem cell niches in the skin, tissue regeneration and how skin cell chromatin remembers stress experienced.Elaine foresees a time when the concept of "memory" extends beyond neurons.

item.title: Richard Sever
item.description: How do you grow embryos outside the womb?Jacob Hanna and I discuss his amazing progress in "stembryology". We talk about the uterine barrier, blending stem cells, the necessary incubation conditions, and going beyond gastrulation in mice and humans. https://youtu.be/fiTKdAQGsDI

item.title: Richard Sever
item.description: An interview with Sean Morrisonhttps://youtu.be/BK1RyNS5u7MSean is optimistic that stem research is delivering on its promises with new treatments for various diseases and a host of new factors and mechanisms identified. He also discuses his recent work on leptin-receptor-positive cells in bone marrow and regulation of innervation by NGF, which might have interesting implications for older patients on beta blockers.

item.title: Carl Zimmer
item.description: Did a small-brained hominin bury its dead in graves, make engravings on cave walls, & master fire? Here's my story on extraordinary claims about the fascinating Homo naledi (& the skeptical reaction from experts) https://www.nytimes.com/2023/06/05/science/ancient-humans-homo-naledi-buried-dead.html

item.title: Alessio Buccino
item.description:
Do you use #neuropixels or #highdensity probes? Are your recordings filling up your hard drives?
We got you covered!In the first preprint from
@AllenInstitute
for Neural Dynamics, we looked at ways to reduce the footprint of #ephys data.https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2023.05.22.541700v2(1/n)

item.title: Alessio Buccino
item.description:
Finally, kudos to all co-authors!
Olivier Winter, David Bryant, David Feng, @svoboda314 and Josh Siegle, and thanks to
@alleninstitute for sponsoring this work! (12/n)

item.title: PLOS Biology
item.description: Why have we not yet solved the challenge of plastic degradation by biological means?Learn more about the science of #plastic biodegradation to help #BeatPlasticPollution on #WorldEnvironmentDay2023 https://plos.io/3IWbVuh

item.title: David Schoppik
item.description: A #nyc street corner for #photography #Fotomontag #Photomonday

item.title: Nabeel Siddiqui
item.description: @sharoz The Python community is not really focused as much on statistical analysis but on industry pipelines. There are often major contributors that have little statistical knowledge. I am sure that this has changed over time, and I don't really mind if someone uses one over the other. However, this reddit thread and its links are worth checking out: https://www.reddit.com/r/statistics/comments/8de54s/comment/dxmnaef/?utm_source=share&utm_medium=web2x&context=3
